entry.title: Preliminary What’s New Information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602
entry.content:
Preliminary version of What’s New information and of the Product Assistance are now available for customers and partners to get a preview on the upcoming new and changed features of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602.

You can find this preview on the current SAP Help Portal page SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (see What’s New section “Preview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602”). To access the Preliminary What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer or the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool.

The RASD tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The preliminary information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 will be available in RASD within the next few days. We recommend using RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you. A valid S-User ID is needed to use the RASD tool and to view all the preliminary content stated above.

For any feedback you may have, try the Commenting Feature for What's New documentation in this release. See this blog for more information.

entry.title: Calculate the Critical Project Path with SAP Project and Resource Management
entry.content:
SAP Project and Resource Management (SAP PRM) enables to do bottom-up project scheduling, offering the flexibility to choose between forward and backward scheduling methods. Additionally, the tool visually highlights critical components in the Gantt Chart. This article provides insights into how the scheduling algorithm operates, the process of identifying critical elements, and the various types of scheduling conflicts that may arise.

Scheduling Method:
While editing the project plan, you have the option to choose your preferred scheduling method. To do so, click the 'Settings' button located in the top right corner. Currently Bottom-Up scheduling available and you can choose between Backward or Forward Scheduling.

Forward Scheduling:
When you select ‘Forward Scheduling’ in the ‘Settings’, the system uses the project start date to align the logical first project plan element (this can be Milestones or Work Packages) that does not have child-elements. Following this, other elements are organized according to their Parent-Child Hierarchy, Finish-to-Start Relationships, or Date Constraints. Then the dates are aggregated into a holistic project timeline. If any sequence conflicts arise, the system provides warnings for the impacted project plan elements (See the following section on ‘Conflicts’).

Backward Scheduling:
Backward scheduling similarly arranges project plan elements, but begins with the project end date, positioning the logical last element that has not child-elements underneath.

Critical Project Element Calculation:
When you click ‘Schedule’, the algorithm calculates both forward and backward scheduling, assigning Early Start and Early Finish Dates for forward scheduling, and Late Start and Late Finish Dates for backward scheduling. The Scheduled Dates are then copied to Planned Dates, which project managers can adjust as needed.

Project plan elements are highlighted as critical—like Critical Milestone or Critical Work Package—and colored red if their Float is zero. This may be due to their position on the critical path or a Must Start/Finish On constraint.

Conflicts:
As previously noted, various factors can lead to conflicts arising. For instance, two elements of a work project plan might not align correctly due to their relationship being out of sequence (refer to image 1), or child dates might not be properly aggregated (refer to image 2). The project plan elements that are impacted are highlighted, and warning messages will assist you in comprehending the conflict more thoroughly.


Image 1


Image 2

Milestone Calculation:
Since milestones lack a duration (they have only a Finish Date), when a Work Package consists solely of milestones as children, the duration of this Parent Work Package remains unaffected by its milestone children. However, this changes if additional work packages are defined as children.

Milestone Display:
Milestones are positioned based on their Finish Date, which is always displayed on the right end of the respective Date Bar.


Additional Information
For general insights into project scheduling with SAP PRM, refer to this blog post or explore specific details on Date Constraints and Bi-Directional Integration. For more comprehensive product details, please visit the product website.

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Adding or Removing Business Contexts
entry.content:
Have you ever been in a situation where you created a key user custom field (called custom field for the rest of this blog) for one business context, and it turned out that you also needed the identical field for another business context? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, we explain which alternatives we offer to propagate a custom field into additional business contexts. Starting with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 releases, it's now possible to propagate an existing custom field to every other business context. In this blog, you’ll learn how to use this new functionality.

How to add a business context to an existing custom field 

From the very beginning, the Custom Fields Fiori app offers two ways to enable an existing custom field for additional business contexts: 

  1. By enabling a business scenario for a custom field, additional business contexts are enabled automatically. The corresponding data flows between these involved business contexts are activated, too. Therefore, custom field data is automatically transferred from one business context to the other in copy processes of the extended applications
  2.  By enabling a standard CDS view for a given key user field that exposes data from several business contexts (this can happen in cases where the CDS view represents a union of different business object nodes) 

So far, so good. But what happens if none of the options above enable you to propagate your existing custom field into your required business context? In this case, you can use our new feature. It allows you to propagate an existing custom field in any arbitrary business context, even if there are no corresponding business scenarios or union CDS views. 

Let’s have a look at how that works. We'll provide a concrete example for the new “Add Business Context” feature: 

Let’s assume you created a custom field “YY1_INVOICE_TYPE” of type code list (with a fixed set of possible code values like “Standard Invoice”, “Partial Invoice”, “Corrected Invoice”, …) for business context “Accounting: Journal Entry Item” (FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM). Afterwards it turned out that you also needed this field for business context “Group Reporting: Journal Entry Item” (FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM).  
 
As there is no business scenario and no union view available that would allow you to propagate the field into the “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” business context, in the past, the only option would have been to  

  1. create another custom field for business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” with a similar name (you can't have the same name twice) and 
  2. define (and later on maintain) the exact same code values for each of the custom fields separately 

With the new “Add Business Context” feature, this is no longer necessary. You simply can add the custom field to the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. 

In the screenshot below, you can see the custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE” that's already been created on the business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. As soon as you select this field, the “Add Business Context” button on the bottom right corner is clickable. 

Custom Field on business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” 

As soon as you click “Add Business Context”, the standard business context search help popup is shown allowing you to select an additional business context. Here, you can choose the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. 

Choosing business context FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM 

As soon as you choose the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”, the business context is immediately added to the custom field. 

Business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” has been added to the custom field 

That’s it. You can now publish the custom field and then you are done. 

Please note that this feature is available starting from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. 

This functionality is also available for SAP S/4HANA 2023 with support package 4. For older support packages it's available via deploying SAP note 3567408 – “Change Type of a Custom Field / Add or Remove Business Contexts to a Custom Field”.  
Please also note that in case the "Add Business Context" button does not become visible after applying this note the reason for that is most likely that the SAPUI5 Application Index entry for the Custom Fields App is outdated and in order to get rid of that problem please apply SAP note 2227577 ( "Recalculation of the SAPUI5 Application Index After Implementing an SAP Note").

Next, let's take a look at how to remove business contexts from a custom field. 

How to remove a business context from a custom field 

Let’s assume that a couple of days after you enabled business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” for custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE”, it turns out that the situation has changed, and you don't need this business context any longer in this custom field. In the past, there was no way to remove a dedicated business context from a custom field.  

With the new feature, it's now possible to remove a dedicated business context from a given custom field. Within the field list shown in the Custom Fields Fiori app, you mark the entry for the business context you want to remove of custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE”. As soon as you've done that, the “Delete” button on the bottom right corner of the screen is clickable. Once you click on the down arrow within the “Delete” button, the option “Remove Field from Business Context” appears (see the screenshot below). 

“Remove Field from Business Context” option in the Custom Fields app 

As soon as you click on this option, a popup is shown asking you whether you really want to delete the field from this business context (see the screenshot below).  

Confirmation popup “Do you want to remove selected field from business context” 

Once you click on “Delete”, the selected business context is removed from the field and the publishing process for this change is automatically triggered. 

With this, you are done. You successfully removed the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” from custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE” 

Custom field successfully removed from business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” 

Congratulations! 
Please note that in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editions, a removal of a business context from a custom field is only possible if the adding of the business context to this custom field has not been released with a software collection so far. Afterwards, you can still delete the entire custom field, but you can no longer choose to only remove the business context you've added. 

This functionality is also available for SAP S/4HANA 2023 with support package 4. For older support packages, it's available via deploying SAP note 3567408 – “Change Type of a Custom Field / Add or Remove Business Contexts to a Custom Field”.  

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Christian Fuhlbruegge(ChristianFuhlbruegge),  and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions. 

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

  1. SAP S/4HANA Key User Extensibility powered by Embedded Steampunk: Custom Field with ABAP implemented Value Help

entry.title: Step-by-step to troubleshooting an authorization issue
entry.content:
The other day, when I logged on to the system and attempted to edit the page layout using “Adapt UI”, I suddenly noticed that the “Adapt UI” option was missing from the user menu.

 

Initially, I suspected this might be related to the new launchpad UI. So I went to “Activate Features” in CBC, turn off the setting /UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE.

 

After refreshing the page, I still couldn't find the "Adapt UI" option under the old UI interface.

 

I remembered that I previously had access to this option in the same system, and I hadn't removed any authorization for my user account. So why had it disappeared?

To investigate the root cause, I needed to verify whether I still had authorization to use "Adapt UI".

I opened the help portal and searched for "Adapt UI" to determine its associated business catalog.

 

Upon clicking the relevant link, I discovered that the business catalog was SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLX_CUS_PC. Meanwhile, I also noticed the IAM app F5933_LRST_TRAN, which reminded me that IAM Apps have now become the smallest authorization unit, rather than business catalogs.

 

At that moment, I realized that the IAM App might have been deactivated. To confirm this, I first needed to identify the business role that contained this IAM App. In the Display IAM Apps, I found that the IAM App F5933_LRST_TRAN was assigned to the Administrator role (BR_ADMINISTRATOR), which I have.

 

To double-check, I went to the Business Catalog and confirmed that the related business catalog was also used in the BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role.

 

I then opened the Maintain Business Roles app, opened BR_ADMINISTRATOR, and under the IAM Apps tab, it confirmed my suspicion - the IAM App F5933_LRST_TRAN was indeed deactivated.

 

I proceeded to edit the business role and reactivated it as follows:

 

After reloading the page and returning to the sales order application, I could finally see the "Adapt UI" option in my user menu!

 

 

Lesson Learnt:

  • IAM App is now the smallest unit for controlling user authorization, not Business Catalog.
  • Some IAM Apps are deactivated by default. Therefore, if you encounter missing authorization issues, always check whether the related IAM App is active.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, AI-assisted back order processing [BOPAI]
entry.content:
Order Promising plays a critical role in the sales process, providing confirmation on product availability, order quantity, and expected delivery dates. Backorder Processing (BOP) is an essential capability that helps Order Fulfillment Managers resolve confirmation bottlenecks. By applying BOP strategies, the system ensures that high-priority or time-sensitive orders are fulfilled first, while lower-priority orders are processed afterward.

With the BOP AI use case, the Order Fulfillment Manager no longer needs to learn the entire sequential process required to schedule a BOP run. Instead, the system simplifies the workflow by aligning order fulfilment with customer priority through intuitive, AI-driven interaction.

To simplify and automate these tasks, the BOPAI use case enables users to execute BOP through a simple, conversational interaction with Joule.

The solution operates in two modes:

(a) Fast Track – Minimal user intervention is required, allowing BOP to run quickly and efficiently.
(b) Guided – The user is prompted to provide inputs such as names and strategy selections, offering greater control and flexibility

Steps of Execution:

  • The user logs into the Fiori Launchpad and initiates Joule to begin an interactive chat.
  • As shown in the below screenshot on the left, the user is presented with a chatbot interface that includes predefined prompts to help kickstart the conversation.
  • The user can either select the “Configure Backorder Processing” option or type any relevant prompt to initiate the interaction process.

When the user clicks the Configure Backorder Processing prompt, two options are presented:

  • Fast Track
  • Guided

Fast Track:
As the name suggests, this option is designed for users who want quick results without getting into the details of each input. The user simply provides the material and plant information, and the system handles the rest, delivering fast and efficient output.

Guided:
This option takes the user through a step-by-step process to create a segment and variant. The user can specify names for both the segment and the variant, and also choose the strategy to be applied for the BOP execution. This mode offers more control and customisation throughout the workflow.

If Fast Track option is selected, the prompt asks the user to provide the product, plant, and simulation status. As shown, the strategy is automatically set to Improve, and the system requests confirmation before proceeding.

The user can now see that the simulation has completed successfully, and the relevant details are displayed for review. If the simulation results are satisfactory, the user can proceed with the actual run. Once the actual run is finished, the updated confirmations are shown, including the processed requirements and any changes to confirmed quantities. With these steps completed, the BOP - Fast Track execution concludes successfully—with minimal user intervention.

Having walked through the BOPAI Fast Track use case, we will now explore the Guided scenario. When the Guided option is selected, the user is prompted to provide the BOP segment name, along with the product and plant details. Once these inputs are entered, the subsequent steps of the guided process are initiated.

At this stage, the segment has been created. The user can either navigate to the Create BOP Segment app to review the newly created segment or proceed directly to the next steps. Before selecting a strategy during variant creation, the user may also choose to explore the available confirmation strategies to make an informed decision.

The next step is to create a variant. When the user selects Create BOP Variant, they are prompted to provide a name for the variant and choose the desired strategy. A simulation is then displayed, allowing the user to verify the details before proceeding. If everything looks correct, the user continues with the variant creation. In this example, the Win strategy is selected. With the combination of the created segment and variant, the system reshuffles confirmations to achieve improved allocation results.

The updated confirmation statuses are displayed for reference. This concludes the process flow of the Guided AI use case. With the BOPAI usecase depicted above, complex backorder decisions become simple, guided, and efficient.

This AI feature is now made available with the Joule Base license without any additional charge from Cloud Edition 2511 (November 2025) release onwards. Experience the BOPAI usecase and feel free to drop-in your feedback to ar.sharma@sap.com

entry.title: Extend the Document Store of Analytical Cell Comments by Developer Extensibility
entry.content:
This blog explains how to extend the Document Store by developer extensibility in Embedded Steampunk of S4 Public Cloud. The following contents are covered:

  • Introduction of cell commenting feature and Document Store. 
  • Prerequisites of Document Store developer extensibility.
  • Extend Document Store by developer extensibility.

1. Introduction of Cell Commenting Feature and Document Store 

In some Review Booklet and Multidimensional Analysis  (MDA) Apps, users might see a “comment” button in the side panel and then users can add comments on a data cell of the grid through the comments side panel. This feature is called Cell Commenting, as shown in the following figure: 

 

To enable the Cell Commenting feature the analytical cube and query must be enabled with Document Store which stores the context of the cell, including the fixed filters in the filter bar, the dynamic filters and the selected dimensions on row and column.

Document Store consists of two artifacts:

  • Document Store Table: a database table to store the cell context.
  • Document Store CDS View: a special category of CDS view which selects from the Document Store Table and has annotation @analytics.dataCategory: #DOCSTORE.

The fields in the Document Store are pure technical fields related to the dimensions of the cube. A dimension in cube can have maximum 6 related fields as following: 

Naming RuleMeaningData Type
TRA_* Transient Characteristic The same data type as the dimension 

SVA_* 

Single Character Variable 

Char(1) 

SVH_* 

Single Variable for Hierarchy 

Char(1) 

HIO_* 

Hierarchy Object 

Char(30) 

HNM_* 

Hierarchy Name 

Char(30) 

HNO_* 

Hierarchy Node Object 

Char(23) 

*: could be the same field name in cube, for example TRA_COMPANYCODE, or a number. The maximum length of the field name in the Document Store is 18, so when the length of cube field name plus the prefix(TRA_, SVA_, ...) exceeds the maximum, a number should be used instead, for example TRA_00001, TRA_00002. Just make sure the field name is unique in the table.

The enablement of Document Store for analytical cube and query include:

  • The Document Store is created for the analical cube view.
  • The analytical cube view is associated to the Document Store CDS view and the association is exposed.
  • The analytical query view contain the Document Store association exposed in cube view. 

For SAP delivered Review Booklets or Multidimensional Analysis applications, if the commenting feature is enabled the above steps have already been done. 

 

2. Prerequisites of Document Store Developer Extensibility 

When a document store enabled cube is extended with a new dimension field by developer extensibility or key user extensibility, the document store will not be extended automatically. In this situation, this new extended field cannot support Cell Commenting. It means if the new dimension is used in the report layout(added in the row or column) or the filter, an error will be raised when you try to create a comment on the cell. Nevertheless, if the new dimension is not used in the report layout or filter, the cell commenting is not impacted, and you can still add comments for the data cells. 

Please be known that if you extend the cube and query with a measure type field, extension is not needed on the Document Store. Only new added dimension fields need the extension in Document Store accordingly. 

There are some prerequisites to extend the Document Store by developer extensibility: 

  • The Document Table and Document CDS View must be C0 released for ‘Use in Cloud Development’.
  • The Document Table should have some extensibility annotations which start with ‘@AbapCatalog.enhancement’. 
  • The Document CDS View should also have the extensibility annotations which start with ‘@AbapCatalog.extensibility’. 

If the prerequisites are not met, please ask SAP to enable the C0 release. 

 

3. Extend the Document Store by Developoer Extensibility

When you have extended the cube with a dimension field, either by developer extensibility or key user extensibility, and want to extend the document store, please follow the steps below. 

3.1 Find Dimention Type

  • Open "Relation Explorer" in ABAP Developer Tool (in the cube right click and select 'Show In→ Relation Explorer) 
  • Check the details on the new-added dimension on the right side, please pay attention to the text in the “[ ]”, it means which kind of dimension it is.  

Ralation Explorer

[Hier] means the dimension has a foreign key association and the association target has hierarchy assocation.

For every new extended dimension field, two types of fields need to be added in the Document CDS View. They are denoted by: 

                  @analytics.document.type: #TRA  

                  @analytics.document.type: #SVA

If the extended dimension has [Hier], four additional fields need to be added in the Document Store CDS View. They are denoted by:

                  @analytics.document.type: #SVH 

                  @analytics.document.type: #HIO  

                  @analytics.document.type: #HNM 

                  @analytics.document.type: #HNO  

As said above, the TRA field should have the same data type as the field in the cube. For key user extensibility case, you can find the data type of new extended dimension in the following way: open the cube view in ADT, and put the cursor on the name of the cube, then press F2 you will see the information of the cube, as the following figure shows:

3.2 Extend the Document Store Table

 Assume a new dimension field PostingLevel_2 has been extended in the cube view. It has a foreign key association I_CnsldtnPostingLevel which has a hierarchy association _PostgLevelHierNode, then 6 fields need to be extended in the document store table and document store CDS view respectively. 

To extend the Document Table, in the ADT of your Embedded Steampunk development system, right click the package, select New -> Other ABAP Repository Object->Structure. Give the name and description, then you can create the structure (which is actually a structure extension). Assume the Document Store table name is ‘test_doc_store_tab’, then a new structure extension would be created with the name  ‘test_doc_store_ext” as the following code: 

extend type test_doc_store_tab with test_doc_store_ext { 
  tra_00062_dcu        : fc_plevl; 
  sva_00062_dcu        : abap.char(1); 
  svh_00062_dcu        : abap.char(1); 
  hnm_00062_dcu        : abap.char(30); 
  hno_00062_dcu        : abap.char(32); 
  hio_00062_dcu        : abap.char(30); 
}

You can also use template ‘appendStructure’ to create the skeleton of the code. 

A correct suffix should be added for the fields according to the definition of annotation @AbapCatalog.enhancement.fieldSuffix  in the Document Store Table. Here ‘dcu’ is used as an example. You should also add prefix before the name for customer development as normal. 

As the length of field name “PostingLevel_2” is more than 13, a unique number should be used instead, normally we are using the existing max number plus 1 to get the number. If the field name is short than 13, please use the field name directly, for example sva_glaccount. 

For field TRA_* the data type should be the same as the field in the cube, so here TRA_00062 uses fc_plevl. 

3.3 Extend the Document Store CDS View

Similarly, 6 fields should be added in the Document CDS View. In ADT, right click the package, select New-> Other ABAP Repository Object ->Data Definition. Write the code as following: 

extend view entity I_CDS_TST_SO_HEADER_CUBEDST with { 
  @analytics.document:{ type: #TRA , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.tra_0062_dcu as tra_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #SVA , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.sva_0062_dcu as sva_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #SVH , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.svh_0062_dcu as svh_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HNM , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.hnm_0062_dcu as hnm_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HNO , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.hno_0062_dcu as hno_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HIO , reference: 'PostingLevel_2 ' } 
  Persistence.hio_0062_dcu as hio_0062_dcu, 
}

You can also use the template ‘extendViewEntity’ to create the skeleton of the code.  

A correct suffix should be added for the fields according to the definition of annotation @ @AbapCatalog.extensibility.elementSuffix  in the Document Store CDS View. Here ‘dcu’ is used as an example. You should also add prefix before the name for customer development as normal. 

Here ‘Persistence’ is the data source of the Document Store CDS View, that is the Document Store Table. Refer to the following example of a Document Store CDS View: 

                       

In the above example, 6 fields are added. For the simple case without hierarchy association, only two fields(TRA_* and SVA_*) are needed.

After the above stpes you will finish the developer extension of Document Store. You can verify the extesion by checking the information of the Document CDS View (press F2 on the view name). Now the users are able to add comments for the new extended dimension.

entry.title: The Power of UI Flexibility in SAP Project and Resource Management
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s fast-moving projects, waiting for a development cycle to adjust a field, add a custom section, or visualize data from another system can slow down productivity.
That’s where UI Flexibility in SPRM Project Management comes in.

UI Flexibility allows key users — not just developers — to adapt and extend their applications without changing the source code. With just a few clicks, you can:

  • Add or reorder sections.
  • Embed external web pages or dashboards.
  • Forward live data from SPRM Project Management into external tools.

Its flexibility designed for business agility.

 

What UI Flexibility Enables

With UI Flexibility, key users can:

  • Create custom sections in the existing application layout.
  • Embed external content, such as web pages, apps, or analytics dashboards.
  • Propagate data from SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT to embedded content via URL parameters.
  • Leverage Public APIs to exchange information between the host app and embedded systems.

[Screenshot – Example of a custom embedded section with an planning calendar]

You can extend your SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT workspace to include the tools and data you use daily.

 

Architecture Overview

UI Flexibility is built on top of the UFlex service and integrates directly with the SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT application framework.
It ensures all extensions stay secure, modular, and maintainable.

Architecture Layers

Layer

Description

SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT Application

Provides the core logic and standard UI containers.

UI Flexibility Layer

Allows runtime configuration of new sections and embedded content.

Embedded Content Layer

Hosts external pages or applications within secure iframes.

Public API Layer

Enables controlled, secure data exchange between SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT and custom apps.

 

[Diagram – UI Flexibility and Embedded Content Architecture]

 

Embedding External Content

UI Flexibility supports embedding external web pages or applications directly within SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT screens.
Below there are examples for possible implementations:

  • Project dashboards
  • Reporting apps
  • Custom micro-frontends
  • Process documentation or help content

Each embedded component runs independently. This ensures that even if one service experiences issues, the rest of your application remains stable.

[Screenshot – Embedded external team calendar example]

Important Note: The embedded app is isolated from SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT. Any data exchange should occur through defined URL parameters or Public APIs only.

 

Data Propagation and Public API Access

How it Works

When configuring an embedded section, you can select which SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT data should be forwarded to the embedded content via the URL i.e. test.com/Projects/{Uuid}/{CollaborationOwner}
This enables the external page to operate in context — for example, knowing which project or object the user is viewing.

Example Uses:

  • Display custom KPIs using project data.
  • Trigger external workflows when a user opens a section.
  • Write back updates to analytics tools using the Public API.

Tip: Combine URL-based data propagation with Public API calls for dynamic, two-way integrations.

 

Technical Insight: Interaction Model

Although UI Flexibility gives freedom to embed and integrate, it respects browser and framework boundaries.

Key facts:

  • Embedded apps are rendered in iframes.
  • Browsers restrict direct event sharing between the host and iframe. This is done via the sandbox flags which can also be removed, but this is not recommended.
  • Edit or Save events in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT are not automatically communicated to the embedded app.
  • Each embedded component should manage its own logic and data lifecycle.

Hint: Design embedded apps as standalone micro-applications that can run independently, even outside the host context.

 

 Example Setup: Creating an Embedded Section


Here’s how to configure your first embedded section using UI Flexibility.

  1. Go to UI Flexibility Settings in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT.
  2. Select “Add New Section”.
  3. Choose Embedded Content as the section type.
  4. Enter the URL of your external web page or app.
  5. (Optional) Select which SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT fields to pass as URL parameters.
  6. Save and refresh — your new embedded section appears instantly.

[Screenshot – UI Flexibility setup]

Result: The embedded content behaves as a seamless part of your interface, while staying fully isolated and easy to maintain.

 

What You Can Achieve

Here’s what teams across projects are already doing with UI Flexibility:

  • Embedding live dashboards that update in real time.
  • Integrating specialized reporting tools.
  • Launching external workflow systems from within SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT.
  • Displaying custom KPIs per project, using propagated data.

 

Visual Demo Plan

For upcoming internal showcases, we’ll include the following visuals:

  1. UI Flexibility – Creating an Embedded Section

     


     

  2. Rearrange sections with UI Flexibility (drag and drop)

     

 

Conclusion

UI Flexibility in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT bridges the gap between business agility and technical governance.
It empowers key users to personalize their workspace, bring in the data and tools they need, and keep pace with changing business processes — all while IT retains control of the underlying architecture.

In short:

You don’t need to be a developer to make SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT work smarter — just flexible.

entry.title: Generating OData Service Artifacts from Multiple CDS Views/Tables
entry.content:
🛠️ Step 1: Initialize the Service Generator

Start the Service Generator tool (often accessed via ADT or a relevant Fiori tool). You will typically begin by defining the main service configuration.

 

 

🔗 Step 2: Define Business Object Entities

The key to multi-entity services is correctly defining all entities and their relationships.

A. Define the Parent Entity (Header)

  1. Add Entity: Start by adding the primary, or "Header," entity. In your case, this is R_S2P_VendMGNT.

    • Entity Alias: R_S2P_VendMGNT

    • Parent Name: Not applicable (as this is the top-level entity)

    • Fields: Define the necessary fields, such as VendorLegalName1, ensuring correct data types and lengths (e.g., Char, length 10).

    • You dont have to pass the key field, it will automatically generate to SAP UUID.

 

B. Define the Child Entity (Item)

  1. Add Entity: Add the secondary, or "Item," entity, which represents the line items. In your scenario, this is R_S2P_VMITem.

  2. Establish Relationship: This entity must be defined as a child of the header entity to enable navigation properties in the final OData service.

    • Entity Alias: R_S2P_VMITem

    • Parent Name: R_S2P_VendMGNT (The header entity)

    • Cardinality: "To Many" - This is crucial as one vendor (header) can have multiple line items (items).

  3. Fields: Define the item-specific fields (your image shows fields being added to R_S2P_VMITem as well).

 

⚙️ Step 3: Review and Generate Artifacts

After defining both entities and their relationship, you can proceed to the generation step.

  1. Review Artifacts: The generator will prepare a list of ABAP Repository Objects to be created. This list confirms the successful configuration of the multi-entity service.

    The generated artifacts will include:

    • Service Definition (ZUI_R_S2P_VENDMGNT...😞 Defines the entire OData service structure and exposes the entities.

    • Service Binding (ZUI_R_S2P_VENDMGNT...😞 Provides a deployable endpoint for the OData service.

    • SAP Object Node Types (ZR_S2P_VENDMGNT😞 Defines the underlying object structure for each entity.

    • Data Definitions (D ZC_R_S2P...😞 Defines the core ABAP structures.

    • Business Object Projection Entities: Maps the CDS entities to the Business Object layer.

  2. Generate: Click Finish to generate these artifacts.

 

🎉 Conclusion

By defining a hierarchical structure where the item entity is a child of the header entity with "To Many" cardinality, you successfully generate all required ABAP artifacts for a robust OData service that handles complex data from multiple source tables/CDS views. This service can now be consumed by Fiori applications to retrieve both header and line item data efficiently.

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 3
entry.content:
Como vimos en los primeros dos blogs Parte 1 y Parte 2, extender SAP Cloud ERP (o comúnmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), es muy importante para adaptarse a la necesidad específica de cada uno de tus clientes.

SAP Cloud ERP puede extenderse dentro de si misma, pero en esta parte final, abordaremos una de las formas óptimas de escalar tu solución y es, mediante el uso de la SAP Business Technology Platform o SAP BTP, mediante el diseño de aplicaciones Multi-tenant y multi-backend, para esto tenemos varios ejemplos dentro de los recursos oficiales de SAP, pero quiero mostrarles el que para mí, es el más relevante para quienes desean comenzar en SAP Cloud ERP y tienen ya prácticas en otro de nuestros productos, como SAP Business One o SAP Business ByDesign.

 

 

 

Proceso de desarrollo para un cliente a múltiples tenants y diferentes Back-ends

Empecemos análizando lo siguiente: en tu empresa tienen una necesidad clara y deciden desarrollar una aplicación específica para un cliente, para ello puedes crearla directamente In-App, usando por ejemplo Key-user o Developer Extensibility en Cloud ERP.

Como segundo análisis, quiero que revisemos lo que pasa, si te das cuenta que esa necesidad es la misma para otros usuarios, el camino entonces, es pensar en una solución multi-tenant, que de hecho puede ser desarrollada dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, usando por ejemplo la Multi-off Delivery o la Scalable Delivery.

Ahora como tercer análisis, ¿qué pasa si te das cuenta que esa aplicación no solo es útil para clientes de SAP Cloud ERP?, sino que tienes clientes de SAP Business One, SAP Business ByDesign, o incluso deseas poner la aplicación como standalone solution y permitir el acceso a clientes que no cuentan con una de nuestras ERPs. Allí se hace muy relevante escalar nuestra aplicación y usar la SAP BTP como centro de desarrollo y despliegue, nos referimos entonces a una aplicación Multi-tenant y Multi-backend o de ERP agnóstico.

 

 

Modelos Operacionales

 

Como partner puedes tener diferentes modelos operacionales, uno de ellos es el modelo “Customer Managed” donde los clientes gestionan directamente la implementación y el mantenimiento de las soluciones, con el apoyo técnico y consultoria del Partner.

Otro modelo es el “Partner SaaS Solutions”, donde el Partner desarrolla y gestiona aplicaciones de software como servicio (SaaS) en la nube, utilizando la plataforma SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). Este modelo permite a los Partners ofrecer soluciones escalables y compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP ERP, proporcionando a los clientes acceso a aplicaciones avanzadas y servicios como inteligencia artificial y machine Learning.

 

 

Partner Reference App: el caso de uso

 

La BTP Partner Reference App es un modelo, que te permite crear aplicaciones directamente en la SAP BTP, diseñadas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, lo cual deja como resultado: fácil integración y mantenimiento de la misma. Incluye ventajas de compatibilidad y eficiencia. El link general de esta aplicación se encuentra publicado en nuestro GitHub  (BTP Partner Reference App).

La BTP Partner Reference app, sigue el modelo de soluciones de Software como Servicio para nuestros Partners. Al estar alojada en la SAP BTP está clasificada como una Side-by-side Extension, este tipo de aplicaciones son operadas desde esta plataforma y cuentan con ciclo de vida propio, independiente del ERP que se use.

Esta aplicación es un imaginario de un Poetry Slam, donde el usuario debe imaginar que es un manager de eventos, quien organiza eventos de poesía, y usa la aplicación para planear y ejecutar los eventos, analizar los costos, comprar equipo, publicar los eventos, manejar las reservas, los visitantes y artistas.

 

Este modelo, sigue los estándares SAP, con un modelo centralizado de identidad y autenticación, un Launchpad común, navegación entre aplicaciones y una integración back-end segura. Tienes dos formas de acceder a esta aplicación y probarla por ti mismo: la primera es ir directamente y clonar el repositorio de Github, o seguir paso a paso desde el desarrollo inicial hasta el modelo final. Si sigues el segundo paso la guía te llevará a:

 

1.     Crear el Core: donde el foco es la lógica, los roles, los modelos y el contenido.

2.     Make it scale: allí entenderás como pasar de una solución para un cliente a una multi-tenant

3.     Connect: Integra la solución con tu ERP preferida

4.     Features: Agrega nuevas funcionalidades, añade servicios, integra con elementos de terceros.

 

 

Tipo de Aplicaciones que pueden seguir este modelo

Pero ¿Cómo saber qué tipo de aplicaciones pueden seguir este modelo?, aconsejamos este tipo de extensión cuando:

-    Son aplicaciones para un grupo separado de usuarios (Usuarios sin ERP)

-    Aplicaciones que deben tener proximidad a SAP BTP para el aprovechamiento de servicios como Machine Learning, AI entre otros.

-    Soluciones que deben ser integradas con diferentes ERPs y servicios en la nube.

 

 

Ventajas de este tipo de aplicaciones

¿Qué ventajas tienen este tipo de aplicaciones principalmente?

-    SAP standard para el desarrollo, experiencia de usuario y diseño

-    Mantener el Clean Core, que te permite acelerar la innovación y estar siempre al día con actualizaciones.

-    Incluir Herramientas de Inteligencia artificial en tus soluciones.

 

 

Partner Journeys posibles

Seguir este modelo de arquitectura, permite tener un diseño que apoye diferentes caminos como Partners:

-    Un Partner de SAP Cloud ERP, puede crear IP que extienda la solución

-    Un Partner Business One puede extender su negocio a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Partner ByD puede extender su solución e IP a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Service Partner, puede crear una solución escalable que por ejemplo provea a una gran compañía con servicios a múltiples departamentos y subsidiarias.

 

 

Integración con SAP Cloud ERP

 

 

Para la integración con SAP Cloud ERP, es importante configurar el SAP Cloud Identity Services, y en la BTP el acceso de Trust Management, los servicios de Destino, entre otros servicios necesarios. Por el lado de SAP Cloud ERP, se deben configurar todos los canales de comunicación, como Communication arrangement, Communication System, etc. , agregar la aplicación como un “custom tile” y poder acceder a ella. 

El diseño de esta aplicación permite la integración en dos lineas, la primera Front-end que le permite navegar a la Aplicación Poetry Slam Manager a los proyectos específicos conectados en SAP Cloud ERP, y la integración Back-end que permite crear un proyecto en SAP Cloud ERP y visualizarlo dentro de la aplicación side-by-side mediante OData APis con el uso del principio de propagación.

 

 

Extender tu aplicación

En la última versión de este ejemplo, también se muestra la opción de adaptar este tipo de aplicación para clientes específicos, ya que hemos visto que aunque sea una solución que resuelva un Problema de muchos clientes, cada cliente tiene sus propias necesidades y adaptarla también genera robustez en la solución.

Al ser una Cloud Application Programming model, o CAP, también se pueden extender:

-    Campos

-    Entidades

-    Aplicaciones Web

-    APIs

 

 

Alcance del mercado al diseñar Multi-tenancy y ERP Agnogstic

Al aprovechar el diseño multitenant y ERP agnogstic, como partner de SAP, puedes aumentar significativamente el alcance del mercado. Este tipo de diseño permite que una sola instancia de aplicación sirva a multiples tenants, lo que implica soluciones escalables y rentables a más clientes, con la posibilidad de compartir servicios y disminuir costos. Además el diseño agnóstico, asegura que la aplicación pueda ser fácilmente integrada a diferentes ERPs, no solo con los de SAP aumentando el atractivo de este tipo de aplicaciones y utilidad en diferentes entornos de clientes. Este enfoque mejora la penetración del mercado y abre oportunidades para entregar soluciones a más clientes independiente de la estructura ERP existente.

 

En estos tres blogs y en español :P, hemos recorrido las diversas opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP, destacando la importancia y las diversas formas de adaptar esta solución a las necesidades de tus clientes. Espero que esta información haya sido útil y te haya proporcionado una visión clara de como escalar tus soluciones.

 

Me encantaría saber que te pareció esta serie, Gracias por leerme.

 

Síguenos via @SAP and #S4HANA o encuéntrame en LinkedIn -> @Monica_Pimiento 

 

Saludos querido mundo SAP Hipanoparlante.

Mónica Pimiento

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations – whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAP’s clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAP’s clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions – especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Own illustration based on SAP source: https://www.sap.com/documents/2018/05/606d1ee8-037d-0010-87a3-c30de2ffd8ff.html)

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAP’s clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs – particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management – which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG (Berufsgenossenschaft) Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAP’s clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field “Business Unit” to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customer’s specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the “Custom Fields” Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the “Custom Fields” app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click “Create”.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the “Custom Fields” Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the “Manage Incident” Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose “Adapt UI”

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting “Customize” > “Show Customizable Areas” as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field “Business Unit” into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on “Customize UIBB”.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select “Element” > “Add Element”.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select “OK”.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the “Maintain Form Template” app.

1. Open the “Maintain Form Template” app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the “Custom Template” tab.

3. Click “New” to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example “YY1_WHS_FORM10” including the prefix “YY1_” for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as “EHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRV”.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the “Custom Logic” app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click “Create” to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to “Step 2” (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select “Code Editor” and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Person’s Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click “Publish” to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or ”Implementation Activities” app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically “SAP Interactive Form”, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the “Maintain Form Template” app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the “Manage Incident” app.

1. Open the “Manage Incident” app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  “In Process”.

3. Click on “Regulations”, choose “WHS”, then click “OK” and” Save”.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the “Reports” tab.

4. Navigate to the “Reports” tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click “Generate” to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click “Generate” for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAP’s clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation – It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity – it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely – Don’t Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs – never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.

 

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal
